title: 112_hr2764
content: The Act titled "WMD Intelligence and Information Sharing Act of 2012" adds a section on Weapons of Mass Destruction Intelligence and Information Sharing to the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Office of Intelligence and Analysis of the Department of Homeland Security supports intelligence analysis of terrorist actors planning attacks involving chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear materials. It also analyzes global biological threats and conducts risk assessments of homeland security hazards. The Office of Intelligence and Analysis of the Department of Homeland Security enhances prevention, protection, response, and recovery efforts for chemical, biological, radiological, or nuclear attacks. It shares tailored analytical support on these threats with State, local, and tribal authorities and other national biosecurity stakeholders. Coordination with relevant Department components, the Intelligence Community, and other authorities is also emphasized. The Secretary of Homeland Security will report annually to congressional committees on intelligence and information sharing activities related to countering weapons of mass destruction, as well as the Department's compliance with relevant intelligence strategies. The Secretary of Homeland Security will provide an annual report to congressional committees on the Office of Intelligence and Analysis' progress in implementing measures for countering weapons of mass destruction. Definitions for 'appropriate congressional committees' and 'Intelligence Community' are also included in the report. The term 'national biosecurity and biodefense stakeholders' includes officials from Federal, State, local, and tribal authorities, as well as individuals from the private sector involved in preventing, protecting against, responding to, and recovering from biological attacks or serious health consequences for the United States. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Act. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to allow the Department to share analyzed information with State, local, tribal, and private entities to prevent terrorism. This amendment was passed by the House of Representatives on May 30, 2012.
